Key Arguments: The Bill threatens free speech and democracy by potentially allowing government overreach and censorship.
Historical examples, such as the Robodebt scandal, demonstrate the importance of social media as a platform for citizens to voice concerns and seek justice.
The Bill could foster conditions similar to fascism by penalizing social media companies, leading to censorship out of fear of financial penalties.
Exemptions for government and educational institutions suggest a move towards a dictatorship.
The Bill could lead to unjust silencing of citizens who challenge official narratives, particularly in the context of public health and safety.
Notable Quotes: The Bill will be negative for free speech and democracy in Australia.
The Bill will create the conditions for the ideals of fascism to thrive in Australia.
Exempting Government and educational institutions from the Bill, gives the impression of a forming Dictatorship in Australia.
